title: Oil Prices Jump After Saudi Strikes In Yemen
teaser: Saudi Arabia's involvement in Yemen's growing unrest has led to fears of instability in the oil market.
contentencoded:
The price of Brent crude jumped 5 percent yesterday as Saudi Arabia began airstrikes in Yemen.Â It was the biggest spike in oil prices since February. The benchmark settled near $60 a barrel.

Saudi involvement in Yemen’s growing unrest has led to fears of instability in the oil market, even though a global supply glut was a primary reason why oil prices have been so low.

Michael Regan of Bloomberg News speaks to Here & Now’s Jeremy Hobson about what continuous Saudi influence in Yemen means for the global oil market.

Guest

  • Michael Regan, editor at Bloomberg News. He tweets @Reganonymous.
